title.native: 美少女戦士セーラームーンS かぐや姫の恋人
title.romaji: Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon S: Kaguya Hime no Koibito
title.english: Sailor Moon S Movie: Hearts in Ice

description: An unusual snow storm hits Tokyo and the Sailor Senshi discover that an evil snow queen Kaguya, wants to freeze the entire earth. It's up to the Inner Sailor Senshi along with the Outers, to defeat the Queen. Meanwhile, Luna falls in love with a human astronomer named Kakeru whose girlfriend is an astronaut about to take a space shuttle mission. Kakeru becomes ill and Luna wishes she could be a human to help him.
synonyms: Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon S: The Movie
Sailor Moon S: Czarodziejka z Księżyca – Film kinowy
Sailor Moon S: Corações de Gelo

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Anthology
tags.description: A collection of separate works collated into a single release.

name.native: プリンセス・スノー・カグヤ

node.description: Naoko Takeuchi is a manga artist who lives in Tokyo, Japan. Takeuchi's works are widely admired by anime/manga fans. She is a well-known mangaka in the United States. Her most popular work, Sailor Moon, has been widely reprinted and marketed in North America. She also wrote the lyrics for a number of songs featured in the Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon anime and live-action series. They are mainly character-based image songs, but do include a few theme songs. She has won several awards including the 2nd Nakayoshi Comic Prize for Newcomers, for “Yume ja Nai no Ne,” in 1985. She also won for "Love Call" which won Nakayoshi's New Artist award which debuted in the Nakayoshi Deluxe September 1986 issue. In 1993 she won the 17th Kodansha Manga Award for shoujo for Sailor Moon. She is also married to the author of Hunter x Hunter and Yu Yu Hakusho, [Togashi Yoshihiro](https://anilist.co/staff/96893).

Affiliated with Studio Live. Admires [Kazuko Tadano](https://anilist.co/staff/118426/).

Her designs are very shoujo manga like, often featuring glittering eyes.

Takanori Arisawa was a Japanese composer and arranger from Tokyo. He wrote the background music for several notable anime, including the award-winning soundtrack of the Sailor Moon anime series.    He died of bladder cancer at 54 years of age.    As the Music Director for Sailor Moon, Arisawa's first award was the 1993 Golden Disk Grand Prize from Columbia Records. He continued to compose for the entire anime series, plus several video games and some of the stage musicals. In 1998, 2000, and 2001 he won the JASRAC International Award for most international royalties, owing largely to the popularity of Sailor Moon music in other nations.    Arisawa expressed an admiration of Hollywood-style music, drawing his initial inspiration for the tone of the Sailor Moon soundtrack from the Charlie's Angels TV series. He frequently made use of symbolism when writing themes for specific characters or groups, borrowing thematic elements from diverse genres and from other countries. As the series progressed, his music gravitated from a pop feeling toward more classical arrangements to represent the protagonist having passed through painful experiences and grown as a person.    Source: Wikipedia

name.native: 桜っ子クラブさくら組

node.description: A Seiyuu Group composed of the original Inner Senshi actresses from the Sailor Moon musicals, including Anza Ooyama, Ayako Morino, Misako Kotani, Kanoko, and Nana Suzuki.  Songs:  Moonlight Densetsu (second version) La Soldier Sailor War

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/).

Sakurabi made his directional debut with [Gunparade March](https://anilist.co/anime/266/). He is a fan of simple and refreshing love stories. As a director he's known for modifying original stories a lot, which has brought him substantial amounts of critique. He is quite infamous for his work as the director of the [Tsukihime](https://anilist.co/anime/169/) adaptation, with most fans disapproving of his changes from the original visual novel.

Amongst his most notable directorial works are [Yomigaeru Sora: Rescue Wings](https://anilist.co/anime/798/) and [Flying Witch](https://anilist.co/anime/21284/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%B1%E4%BC%8A%E9%87%8C%E5%BC%A5) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iriya_Azuma)

Iriya Azuma is a producer affiliated with [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/).

Married to voice actress [Noriko Uemura](https://anilist.co/staff/103753/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Tastufumi_Itoh) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/伊藤達文)

While still in Morioka, he and three of his friends produced a short anime film titled Bakuhatsu Choujin Kanada Man (爆発超人・金田マン), which was inspired by renown animator [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/). The film was screened at an amateur film festival in 1985 and subsequently featured in the anime magazine Animage.

In 2008, he married fellow animator [Mariko Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/120064/), and changed his name to Itou.

Passed away from a brain hemorrhage on May 23, 2020.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/m_tomisan) | [Blog](http://blog.livedoor.jp/lmtomi/)

Originating from Studio Live. Currently freelance.

Shibata is a japanese animator and animatior director currently working at Toei Animation. He is the father of the mangaka [Yuusaku Shibata](https://anilist.co/staff/107002) and [Hikari Shibata](https://anilist.co/staff/127324).
